entry.title: Combined summary - New transaction policies (nVersion=3) for contracting protocols
entry.summary: The Bitcoin development team has proposed a new set of mempool and transaction relay policies, known as BIP-325, to assist Layer 2/contract protocols. The aim of this proposal is to improve the replace-by-fee (RBF) feature by introducing version 3 transactions (V3). These V3 transactions have a maximum size limit of 1000 virtual bytes, which helps reduce the costs associated with fee-bumping transactions. For V3 transactions, the existing standardness rules still apply, but there are additional rules specific to V3. Firstly, a V3 transaction can be replaced even if it does not signal BIP125 replaceability. This allows for easier replaceability signaling when descendants of unconfirmed transactions are created. Secondly, an unconfirmed V3 transaction cannot have more than 1 descendant. This is to prevent a pinning attack where a malicious counterparty adds many descendant transactions that aren't fee-bumping. Thirdly, a V3 transaction that has an unconfirmed V3 ancestor cannot be larger than 1000 virtual bytes. This sets an upper bound on the size of the child transaction to limit the potential cost of replacement and ensures that the child only needs a few UTXOs to fund the fee-bump.The proposal includes modifications to the package RBF rules, such as requiring all package transactions with mempool conflicts to be V3. Commitment transactions in the Lightning Network are expected to be V3 and include one anchor output. They can be signed with zero fees or 1 satoshi per virtual byte once package relay is deployed on a significant portion of the network. If the commitment transaction needs to be broadcasted, the desired feerate should be determined at that time, and the anchor output should be spent in a high-feerate transaction. The child transaction, which is used for fee-bumping, must also be V3 and have a size of no more than 1000 virtual bytes.The proposed changes aim to provide inherited replaceability signaling when creating descendants of unconfirmed transactions and prevent pinning attacks by malicious counterparties. However, it is acknowledged that the proposal does not address all pinning attacks possible. There are ongoing discussions about potential improvements, including allowing OP_TRUE to become a standard script type and having a single dust-value output that is immediately spent by the package to simplify anchor design.Overall, these proposed policies aim to address rule#3 pinning and provide more flexibility and efficiency for L2/contract protocols. The author acknowledges that there may be limitations and potential pinning attacks, but encourages feedback to improve the proposal.
